column2: Brugor, 75 or over Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have used it for about six months. I may be getting resistant to it.  It used to last 6 hours, now only lasts about 4 hours.  I tried Qvar inhaler and Singulair pills, which have no effect on me at all.  Proventil is effective, although slower to act than the old albuterol.

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just started but it seems to be working for me.  I was wheezing and my breathing was off.

column2: missy, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My Dr gave me one of these inhalers because I am having shortness of breath due to anxiety..but find it doesn't really help.  I've never used an inhaler before..but this one doesn't seem to make any difference.

column2: Gerbil89, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: When I feel an asthma attack coming, it helps within about 10 minutes, but the after effects drive me nuts. Sometimes I'd rather deal with the asthma attack. My hands shake, I get a headache, my heart starts racing and sometimes it makes it hard to BREATH. It works when I absolutely need it but I think I might try ProAir instead.

column2: on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
mmartin, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had asthma for 22 years.  In the past, I have only had to use my inhaler if I was ill or sometimes following exercise.  I'm not sure if my asthma has gotten worse, or if it's a casualty of this replacement inhaler.  The new Proventil HFA is NO WHERE CLOSE to being as effective as the old Albuterol inhalers.  I am all for decreasing the amount of CFC's we release into the ozone, but are inhalers seriously that big of a concern compared to all of the factories, air conditioners, etc. that spew CFC's ALL DAY EVERY DAY?  I went to pick up my refill today, and was shocked to learn it's $68 (I am a student and without insurance).  I have to wonder if the EPA and Big Pharma are in on this together, or if it's just a "happy coincidence".  Nearly every post I have seen and nearly every person I talk to says they have to use this BS inhaler more often, and that it is significantly less effective.

column2: betty, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been using this medicine for two weeks now and find that I have to use it more to relieve my breathing. Also now I have muscle cramps in my lower leg. This is one of the side affects, I am going to ask the Dr. if there is anything else I can take to relieve my asthma.

column2: rancholoma1, 75 or over Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
orangejello1984, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on a generic abuterol inhaler for almost 15 years. I can't believe they stopped making it. I'm disgusted with the fact that I have to pay $40 for a rescue inhaler when my old one worked just as well. It's great that someone wanted to clean up the environment, but it's criminal that they are charging everyone at least $35 for an inhaler that used to cost $5. This is a medication that some people can't live without and with the new prices, people can't afford it. I'm livid that there is no generic available. I'm half tempted to lock myself in a closet for the next 2 years while I wait for a generic because I simply can't afford to be out and about in a world full of allergens when I have to pay $40 for my inhaler! Ridiculous.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I LOVE this inhaler! I was using regular albuteral and almost ended up in the hospital. This inhaler helped immediately! I am able to breathe freely, it's a wonderful thing!

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Now I can't speak for everyone, but I agree with everyone 110%... I really miss the old albuterol sulfate! This medication isn't very effective and I find myself constantly using more than what is prescribed. Also, no matter how hard I puff... it never seems to be despensing the medicine, you could hear and feel my old inhalier working... but this one does work after a while. Just do yourself a favor and get a different perscription; because this one is worthless for emergencies! The only reason i'm still using it, is because it's only a $2.50 co-pay with my insurance. Which, by the way, is really all this crapp is worth.

column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was changed to this inhaler and it does not work. I finally got so tired of having to spend my day (puffing)that I went and got my Asmanex filled and am starting it tonight. Hopefully that will take care of it and I wont need this useless inhaler!

column2: mrs s1, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I want the old one back!!!!!!This inhaler is terrible!!!!!!It does not work half as well and I find I need to use it more.Please find a way to bring back the old one!!!!!!!!

column2: Zoom, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am 67 COPD use in conjunction with steriod inhaler. A better replacement for Abuteral than Proair. Could improve cover cap. It falls off.

column2: none, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: DOES NOT WORK!I was prescribed this for an upper respiratory infection- and it doesn't work at all! Iv'e had albuterol in the past and it worked!!! Are the drug companies trying to keep us sick?!!!!I wonder.

column2: lgomez, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I'm a 26 year old asthmatic and I hate this new Albuterol all Albuterols are the same the generics or brand names the problem is once they made the HFA the medication strength doesn't work the same. I find myself using more and more often as before I only needed a puff once in awhile now I use it like 4 puffs or more specially when I really have a severe asthma attack. I believe if its not broken don't fix it. We were all doing very well with the old one. At work since I'm also a repiratory therapist every one of my patients complain of how ineffective this new inhaler is. Specially for our eldery patients they find them self more in the hospital because they find no reason to use their inhaler since it doesn't work for them.

column2: Beth, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have used Albuterol for the last 8 or 9 years.  When they took it off the market I was put on this and it DOESN'T work.  AND I think i'm allergic to something in it but its the only thing I can take when a sudden attack comes on(even though it really doesn't work).

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been using this inhaler for the past 10 months.  I am not happy with it.  I feel like I have to use more of it than I ever had to use my albuterol inhaler.  After I use it it makes me feel sick to my stomach.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: Well,my six year old daughter has been on this medication for about 6 months and at first she could not breath through the night,she would cough & have problems breathing. But, now she sleeps all night with out having any problem of breathing.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have only been using this inhaler for about 6 months as opposed to the 6 years I used my other inhaler.  This one does not work most of the time!  I feel like I am constantly needing more medicine, since it hasn't controlled my attacks as well as I need it to.  I'm going to the doctor next week to hopefully try something different...

column2: 756emt, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Proventil as a rescue inhaler for my asthma attacks....I was put on ventolin before. I started this medicine and my blood pressure has increased dramatically..Im 23 with it ranging from 140/100 to 122/100. And before i began the Proventil it was 110/70 all the time...This drug works well but the risk of highblood pressure is too great.

column2: Cindy, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Not effective at all! Need my other albuterol inhaler.  Having more difficulty breathing.  Just hoping my MD can help with something else.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This generic is AWFUL! It burned my lungs and the more I used it, the worse the asthma got and sooner it returned. Perhaps it was the carrier chemicals because Ventolin's albuterol was soothing and long lasting. My insurance wouldn't let me choose so I went OTC with Primatene rather than use Proventil.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: It works but there are cheaper alternatives such as Ventolin.

column2: Ann, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: When using this medication I get a very warm uncomfortable feeling in my chest and lungs. It makes me sick on my stomach. I used the albuterol (old one) for 33 years and never had a problem. For myself taking that one off the market was a very big mistake for severe asthma suffers. I wish I new where to order the real inhaler.

column2: COPD sufferer, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been on Symbicort for 2 years. Proventil works so much better in opening the airways. Cost with no insurance is $48 at WalMart. It's worth it to be able to breath.

column2: wmccloud, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It works!!!!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My Dr. put me on this for COPD. I find it works quickly and is easy to use. Will continue with the treatment.

column2: LadyDazzell1954, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It works wonders but my insurance did not pay but only $1.00 on this. What else works this well at a lower price. This is not the only medication I take, and when I picked it up I was floored as to the cost of this medication.If I did not need it I would of not gotten it.

column2: Charlotte, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm taking this inhaler for 1 week for bronchitis. The aftertaste isn't good, but it effectively clears my bronchial tubes. I would take again if needed.

column2: Tony.A, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: opens airway very fast. I have to discharge it before using to make sure the med is being released. Better if it had a counter on it like Ventolin.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
vvndave@tampabay.rr.com, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It's great.Easy to use, no after taste.

column2: Crytical, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: While Proventil *seems* to have a softer spray than plain albuterol (CFC inhalers), I find it easier to use. It doesn't seem as if most of the med ends up on the back of my throat. The taste is also far better :-) I just switched and I don't think I'll go back! While a regular albuterol inhaler only costs me $4 each and Proventil is a $30 copay, it's worth it.

column2: Candy56, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: It works really well for me.  I was on a generic brand and it wasnt as good as this.

column2: vegas44, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: The only drawback to this drug it makes you tremble, and if that is the least side effect to my recovering than I say "Bravo"

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have a hard time with the amount of spray coming out

column2: returtle, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: do not know yet.
